1.content:
Welcome to Morriston. The people here eye strangers with suspicion. The population is well below three hundred people as far as the U.S. census can tell. People tend to go around it when they can, and see those who dare stay a night or even enter the town as foolish. Welcome indeed now who are you.

1.title: Welcome to Morriston ( now get out)

11.content:
You really drew the short straw at your department this time. Everyone in the Florida Census Bureau dreads being the one who has to go to Morriston. The people are very uncooperative, and sometimes hostile. There are stories of Bureau members entering the town and never being heard from again. You drive down main street In your company car,a black Cadillac, and survey the town you will be staying in for the next three days.

You see very few people on the sidewalk. Most of them are young teenagers with dull bulging eyes ambling in small groups. The few adult males you see look a little off. Perhaps there is a lot of inbreeding in this town. With their lack of outside contact it wouldn't be too unbelievable. There are many buildings with boarded up windows, but as you pass them you get the feeling you are being watched. There is one motel in town with the generic name "Morriston motel", one small grocery store, one restaurant. and a fishing port. The city gets most of its money from the fishing industry and has little big business besides the fishing port.

You'll be here for three days going from door to door and figuring the population of the city, so you have to find a place to stay. You're awfully hungry though, maybe you should grab a bite to eat first.
11.title: a view of Morriston

choices: the sooner I get done working the sooner I leave
111.content:
The motel is poorly kept. The paint is peeling and cobwebs line the walls. An old man (the only old person you've seen since entering the town) stares at you indifferently from the other side of the counter. He doesn't look touched like the people on the street, but there is something unwholsome about him. "I'd like a room please" you say to him nervously. He pretends he doesn't hear you. "Excuse me" You say but he cuts you off "one hundred dollars per night." That seemed a little steep, but you didn't want to argue with the jerk, so you payed him for all three nights in advance. He stared at you as if he was waiting for you to leave. "key" you said. He grunted and handed you the key. "Water's not working, hope you don't mind" You mumble a response under your breath and head upstairs. You are in room 208. There is a dingy bed with sheets that have various dark splotches from unknown sources, a small chest of drawers with a lamp on it and a restroom. The lamp doesn't have a lightbulb in it, but for some reason this doesn't surprise you. Cobwebs have formed in the toilet and it doesn't flush. "perfect. I have to stand three days of this!?" You decide it would be best to spend as much time as you can away from the motel.
The man at the front desk gives you the creeps.

I'm with the census beurau and-" "I've got no business with you. Go away" The woman glares at you with her unblinking eyes. Her big lips pursed tightly. She looks young, but her neck is very wrinkly. Seeing that you'll get nothing from her you head on your way. Many of the windows of the building in the residential side of main street are boarded up. You feel eyes staring at you from the empty sockets of these corpses of buildings in this graveyard that was once a thriving town. You finally find a house that has signs of life. It is a little more maintained than the previous buildings, but is still very dilapitated. You ring the doorbell and hear nothing. Must be broken. You knock on the door. There is no answer. As you start to walk away the door opens. "What do you want!" A gruff voice calls from within the shadows of the door. "I'm with the census Beurau, and I just have to ask you a few questions." "Not interested" the voice growls from inside."Sir you're required by law to cooperate." The man grunts and opens the door."make it quick." he stares at you bored. His eyes are bulgy and don't blink. He is balding and his lips are big. His skin has a grey tint to it, his nose is flat, and his ears are almost nonexistant. "Are you the man of the house?" He looks at you like you're an idiot. "No, I'm the woman, what does it look like?" "righ, how many people live with you?" "Just me and my wife" "What religion are you. Catholic, Protestant,Jewish, Islamic, Hindu, Bu-" "I am of the Esoteric Order of Dagon" he cuts you off. "Cute" you say and mark him down as an athiest. You ask him a series of questions getting many snide answers and answeres in dodgy ways. you thank him for his time, he grunts, and slams the door in your face. One down, about two hundred to go. This is going to be a long three days.

12111121.content:
The hunched man goes in, his breath hissing. You follow, keeping low and quiet. Fortunately, most of the windows are broken, and the boarding up job was poorly done, so there are plenty of gaps for you to look through.
As you look through, you see naught but the inky darkness , but you hear the gasping and the hissing of the old man. He seems to be whispering something, but it's to unclear for you to make out. The little fragments you can sound like no language you've ever heard. There seems to be a reply, from the girl, in the same unclear words. As you listen, her voice changes. It is not the voice of a little girl,but something else. It becomes more guttural,and seems to rise in tone. It sounded bass and primal.
"Flechs't tla R'leyh wgahl nhula."
At least that what it sounds like to you. It makes no sense. There is some further conversation, but it can't be made out. There's an eerie, all pervading silence for a moment, then the sound of metal scraping on metal. Then a single, sharp desperate,cry, and the sound like some great door slamming.
Then, shuffling footsteps tell you the old man is coming back. Quickly, you run around the corner and hide. He opens the door, and scans around. Seeing no one he exits, and takes out a large key from his coat pocket and uses it to lock a padlock on the door. All the time, he mutters something over the lock and key. As he rises, he sniffs the air, like an animal, as if smelling something that didn't belong there. Apparently satisfied, he walks away, fading into the dark.

121111212.content:
It's senseless to try the door, but, perhaps the window? The boards on them seem rotten and worm eaten. As you push against them, they snap, releasing a cloud of particles into thre air, as well as a dank smell of mold. You hope the sound wasn't heard, and you wait several moments, lest the gnarled man comes back to investigate.
After that time, you clear the rotting boards away as best as you can. Inside, you see naught but Stygian darkness. Grabbing the sill, you bring your body through the crumbling stone of the wall. The sound of your landing doesn't echo, which you don't really notice at first. You rise, and feel the air. It feels thick, like it actually has a palpaple mass somehow.
You pull out the flashlight from your pocket and shine it. The beam seems to actually get lost in the darkness. Walking in the direction of the beam, then you notice your shoes make no echo noise. For a place this large, it must echo, why is there none?
"Hello?" you try. For a moment there is just the overwhelming silence.
"Who's there?" you hear faintly.
"Where are you?"
"I think it's the center of the room."
You try to follow the voice. Sweeping the floor with the flashlight, you see faint footprints that you think must have been the hunched man. Something else is near it. As you explore further, you see lines and what look to be ancient writings on the floor. They're no language you're familiar with. They go in a large circle.
"Hello?" you hear again. As you swing the flashlight up, you see an old iron cage in the middle of the runic circle. In the cage is the little girl.
" You're the one that was following us." she said plainly.
"Uh, yes" you swing the light up to get a better look at her. She looks like any blonde girl, maybe 10 or 12, but something about her doesn't look....right.
"Why are you here?" you ask her, still trying to shine the light on her. You don't want to get any closer. Experience and instinct is telling you not to cross the magic circle.
"That man.. he's going to kill me! " she whimpered. A tear goes down her cheek. Then you see it! Her eyes! The irises are so dark, they appear black! It looks like she has one large pupil.
"He'll kill me!"
"Why?"
"I don't know!" she reached her arms out of the cage towards him. ""Help me, Mister, please!."
" I don't know if I can."
"You have to, or I'll die! Please!."

Do you...

No, you think. Instinct kicks in. Deep in the recesses of your mind, it all seems wrong. You start to back away from the circle.
"Where are you going?" asks the girl.
"Look, I'll get help from the village, OK?" You continue to back away slowly. With those word, the girl's whole demeanor changes. She let out a long howl that seemed too loud for a girl of her size to make.
"No, you fool!" Her voice changed. It became, slippery,almost as if it could creep around the room. It had a presence that could be felt.
"Do that and were both dead." It seemed to echo forever in your brain, reaching into it, compelling you to listen to it. You stop backing up, even though you don't want to. You try to fight against it, but you can't.
"What you will do is come forward and open this cage." Again the voice reached out, like tentacles. Impelling you to come forward. Despite your strongest efforts, you find yourself moving forward again, towards the dreaded circle.
"Yes." Is all you hear. You're helpless, despite all your strength. The voice is all there is. It fills the room. Your dread grows stronger as you near the circle. You manage to hesitate on the edge, but the drive to cross it is literally pulling your flesh over the border.
From behind, a hand grabs you by the collar and throws you down to the ground. As you hit the ground, you hear a voice yell "Weak minded fool!"

Note by Necessity: I write this in Pietroschek Prose, not US-English, nor British English. Pietroschek Prose is something like unintentional, imbecilic-moronic violation of the two English versions to which it is often mistakenly compared to.

You go back to your make-shift bed, as you still ignore the weirdly stained bed reminding you of a murder. Sleep overcomes you, and your body relaxes a bit. Dreams of unexpected lucidity entertain you for a while.

Dream: You walk down a subterranean tunnel in a happy mood. Your dream-self likes the smell of earth mixed with salty water. You feel good. Just for one moment something alarming crawls upon the outlines of your conscious mind, yet you fell so good that you suppress it with ease.

You know your family awaits you down at the shrine. While the tunnels height forces you to crouch a bit, you are energetic in striding forth. Your family always prays at the shrine since the harsh winter in 1809.

"Our gods ain't almighty, yet them always keep their parts of them bargains!" That statement of your grandfather had impressed you, when you were younger. Nowadays you recognize the flawed, and outdated English. Yet you remember as well, the proud defiance, which your independence-loving grandfather meant with it beyond all academic explanations.

Finally you step into the small cave, which includes the shrine. Your family smiles at you, and you smile back. Once more a darker insight escapes your dreaming minds, as their features are actually just like yours. While you pull the robe over your head, you feel severe pain in your belly, and around the kidneys.

"No way back now - Them said it is to be him tonight!" you hear your father say, while despite the pain you handle the robe. Seeing clearly once more you look upon your family, the alien expression on their faces, and finally the strangely formed obsidian sacrificial knives in their hands!

They stabbed you in cold blood, as you are the intended victim tonight. Before you can say anything they charge you once more. Their knives make weird sounds, when they stab into your body. While you bleed to Death they heave their sacrifice upon the altar...

You had only one memory of them and that was a story your mother had told you before she died. She had said, "They are private people and don't really like traveling they don't have a phone either, but they would love you I just know it".

You find the address you had previously googled fairly easily. You slow down as you turn from the pavement onto the gravel drive. The small stones crunch beneath your tires as you speed up a little. Not to far off the road you see a house come into view.

It is a two story house with faded peeling white paint. Several of the windows have been broken out and ply wood now covers them. The closer you get to the house the more you start to regret your choice to come unannounced. The yard had dead yellow grass waist high a fence had fallen in disrepair long ago still went unnoticed by its owner.

Your stomach twitches and rumbles nervously inside your shirt. You have the strangest feeling wash over you as you pull your car to a stop in front of the run down house. You get out and cautiously close the door, looking around for any sign of your grandparents.

As unsettling as the house looks it is a shelter, and you're getting soaked.

You head for the nearest "abandoned" house choosing convenience over quality...not that any of the other houses look much better. The porch is sagging and the wood looks warped and rotten in spots.

As you walk up to the door you see that the boards holding it in place have been warped and broken for a long time. The doorknob is rusted but with a little effort you manage to open it. A rush of stale and somewhat fishy air rushes out when you open the door. You cough a bit and decide to breathe shallow breaths to avoid the smell as much as you can. There were marks in the dust as if something had dragged or shuffled all over the living room, but he furniture was untouched. The dust on the furniture was so thick you could no longer tell what color the couch in the corner was.

The farther you walk into the livingroom the stronger the fish smell gets.

You decide that since you're not going anywhere you might as well write for a while. You open your laptop case(thankfully it's waterproof) and look for an outlet.

you see none.

there could be one further in the house. You have a battery but you don't know how long it will last.

what now?
1552.title: delapitated house

15521.content:
Not wishing to have your battery go out before you have a chance to save you decide to look for an outlet and hope the power is still on in the house.

As you search for an outlet your hope of there actually being power in the house diminishes completely. There's no way anyone has lived here in years. On the walls there are picture frames with mold behind the glass so bad that the pictures are completely covered.

Suddenly you hear a scraping, dragging noise comming from the basement. It sounds too big to be rats. maybe someone else has sought shelter here as well.
15521.title: just like home

choices: You run, terrified, out of the house.
You're scared, but your writers' inquistive nature wants you to explore more.
155211.content:
It certainly sounds as if someone is dragging something in the basement. You locate what appears to be the basement door. You place a hand on the door knob, and you realize that your hand is trembling. You call out, "Hello?" You try to make your voice sound as friendly as possible, but you find it difficult to disguise a gnawing fear.
'Hello?" you holler out again. "Anyone there?"
You peer down onto the dark basement steps. The scrapping sound suddenly stops. You rationalize that the sound must have been rats after all. You're high-pitched voice scared them into silence. But then you hear voices coming from another room. You can't decide if you're relieved or terrified that you aren't alone in the house. The voices are coming from another room, a dining room perhaps. You near the dining room door and the voices become more distinct.
"You can't kill the damn thing." An elderly man says. "I tried... couldn't kill it with my shotgun."
You hear a younger man's voice: " I say we gather up all the women and children and take a stand, right here in the house."
Who are these people, you're wondering. Take a stand against what? You open the dining room door and terror rushes from your face to tingled your arms. The room is completely empty of people.
155211.title: call out to them

info.brief_description: a Lovecraftian story. search for the truth and try to stay sane.
info.description: Morriston is an insignificant small town off the coast of Florida just between the Florida Alabama border. The citizens usually keep to thier selves and only deal with "outsiders" when they really have to. You are a person {tourist, investigator, commuter} who is in the wrong place at the wrong time. Keep the story dark but imply what happens. Horror is about what you don't show. Keep the continuity of the story and have fun. I'm basing this on H.P. Lovecraft's work, but if you aren't familiar with his stories feel free to make stuff up. Just keep it in the horror genre and try not to let the main character know too much.
